repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in 43 record cartons and 1 manuscript box.

did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English and Yiddish, with a few items in Spanish and French.
did.abstract: Morris U. Schappes (1907-2004) was a scholar, editor and activist who was fired by the City College of New York after being investigated as a Communist Party member, and who spent over a year in prison (1943-1944) for perjury after refusing to name other Party members when testifying before an investigating committee of the New York State Legislature. He was a founder and longtime editor of the progressive, secular magazine Jewish Currents; a popular lecturer; and the author of articles, reviews, radio broadcasts, books and monographs, many of them on U.S. Jewish history. This collection contains correspondence, published and unpublished writings, clippings and other printed ephemera, research materials and documents produced by various progressive organizations. In addition, there is a considerable quantity of Jewish Currents editorial correspondence, Editorial Board minutes and administrative files.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials Note
separatedmaterial.p: Photographs have been transferred to the Non-Print Department (PHOTOS 154)

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; The Morris Schappes Papers; TAM 179; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Morris U. Schappes (1907-2004) was a scholar, editor and activist who was fired by the City College of New York after being investigated as a Communist Party member, and who spent over a year in prison (1943-1944) for perjury after refusing to name other Party members when testifying before an investigating committee of the New York State Legislature. He was a founder and long-time editor of the progressive, secular magazine Jewish Currents; a popular lecturer; and the author of articles, reviews, radio broadcasts, books and monographs, many of them on U.S. Jewish history.

Born Moishe Shapshilevich in Kamenetz-Podolsk, Ukraine, Schappes spent his earliest years in Brazil and then moved with his parents to New York City in 1914. Bureaucrats reduced the family name to Schappes and his mother Americanized his name as Morris. He added the middle “U” later as part of his byline as a sportswriter on the newspaper of City College of New York (CCNY), where he graduated in 1928 and subsequently joined the faculty as an English lecturer. (He had previously attended Townsend Harris Hall High School.) He also attended Columbia University as a graduate student, earning a master’s degree in 1930. In that same year, he began his sixty-two year marriage to Sonya Laffer, who died in 1992.

A longtime fixture in the world of American Communism, Schappes gained widespread attention in 1941 when he was fired, along with 40 others, from the faculty of CCNY for Communist Party membership or involvement. The school had first attempted to dismiss him in 1936 for his political activities but he was retained as the result of a student protest. Later he served 13 1/2 months (1943-1944) in prison for perjury after refusing to name other Party members before New York’s Joint Legislative Committee on the State Education System (known as the Rapp-Coudert Committee). After his release from prison, Schappes worked briefly in a war production factory in Queens and, in 1946, joined with other Party activists to found the magazine Jewish Life, which became an unofficial Party organ. He supplemented his income by freelance lecturing and writing.

As a scholar, Schappes first achieved some prominence for his work on the poetry and letters of Emma Lazarus, and he published a number of books and monographs between 1944 and 1987. Having developed a strong interest in Jewish history while serving in prison, he subsequently published two broad historical studies: A Documentary History of the Jews in the United States, 1654-1877 (1950) and The Jews in the United States: A Pictorial History, 1654 to the Present (1958).

In the early 1950s, Schappes experienced another brush with government committees when the State Department began a purge of books from the shelves of overseas libraries operated by the United States Information Agency. The U.S. Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, chaired by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, held hearings to support McCarthy’s demand that 30,000 “Communist books” be removed, including Schappes’ A Documentary History of the Jews…. In April of 1953, Schappes was subpoenaed and appeared before the committee to defend his books and to attack McCarthyism.

After Nikita Krushchev’s 1956 speech denouncing the misdeeds of Stalin, the subscription base of Jewish Life began slipping away and the magazine’s staff joined many of the rank-and-filers in their disillusion with the Communism they had known. The result was the founding of Jewish Currents, with Morris Schappes as its editor; the journal, independent of Party discipline and financing, would become an intellectual home for an increasingly diverse base of (mostly) secular Jewish leftists.

Schappes dedicated more than four decades to Jewish Currents, and to shaping the views of its enthusiastic and loyal readership. In his “Editor’s Diary” column, he reported on books, plays, films and events in the progressive Jewish movement and engaged in a number of noteworthy controversies, including a historical defense of American Jewish responses to the Holocaust; commentaries about solidarity and tensions between U.S. Jews and African-Americans; and his concerns about antisemitism in Shakespeare’s The Merchant of Venice. Schappes played an active role in the day-to-day management of Jewish Currents until 2000.

Throughout his working life, he was a sought-after lecturer and commentator on Jewish affairs and wrote many articles, essays and letters to the editor in a variety of newspapers, magazines and journals. In 1981, the faculty senate of City College formally apologized for firing him and his colleagues.
Morris Schappes died in New York City on June 3, 2004. He was 97 years old.
Douglas, Martin, “Morris Schappes, Marxist and Jewish Scholar, Dies at 97”, New York Times (June 9, 2004).
Forward Staff, “Leftist Magazine Editor Morris U. Schappes, 97, Dies”, Forward, http://www.jewishcurrents.org/schappes.htm , July 17, 2008.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, published and unpublished writings, clippings and other printed ephemera, research materials and documents produced by various progressive organizations. The Schappes Papers reveal a man of widely varying interests, radical views, strong opinions and devotion to the magazine he helped found -- Jewish Currents. The collection provides not only a glimpse into Schappes’ personal life and his involvement with the American left, but also a record of the day-to-day management the magazine itself.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Investigation Files of the Rapp-Coudert Committee (TAM 533, R-7860)
Which side were you on? the American Communist Party during the Second World War: Interview Transcripts and Summaries, 1977-1978, Maurice Isserman (OH 51 - Transcript)
Frederic Ewen Audiotape and Videotape Collection. Contains a 120-minute videotape of Morris Schappes (OH 52)

Another important source of archival material concerning the life and times of Morris Schappes is the American Jewish Historical Society (AJHS). Schappes (and Jewish Currents staff) made donations to the AJHS Library in 1968, 1979 and 2004. The 1968 donation is especially relevant as it focuses on Schappes' dealings with the Rapp-Coudert Committee and his time in prison, represented by court documents, trial notes, pamphlets, newspaper articles, press releases, and prison rules and regulations. Of particular interest is the correspondence, which includes many letters of support written during his legal battles and prison correspondence with his friends, with servicemen (1943-1946), and with his wife, Sonya. The remainder of the collection consists of materials Schappes generated and collected between 1931 and 1990 in connection with his professional work as a scholar, writer and editor. (See AJHS finding aid.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The collection contains the following series and subseries:
Series I: Personal Papers, 1913-2003
Series II: Jewish Currents Files, 1958-2004
Subseries IIA: Minutes
Subseries IIB: Correspondence
Subseries IIC: Administrative Files
Series III: WBAI Broadcasts, 1966-1994
Series IV: Subject Files, 1911-2004
Series V: Audio-Visual Files, 1966-2000
Subseries VA: Audio Cassettes
Subseries VB: Reel-to-Reel Tapes
Subseries VC: Video Cassettes (VHS)
Subseries VD: Audio Cassettes Addendum
Subseries VE: Reel-to-Reel Tapes Addendum

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Morris Schappes and Jewish Currents staff in a series of donations from 1996 to 2004. An addional gift of four post cards was donated by Swarthmore College in 2013. The accession number associated with this gift is 2013.037.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p:
The Schappes donations spanned a number of years and there had been several attempts to ‘arrange’ the earlier materials. Also, at the time of the final donation (after Schappes’ death), the removal of materials from his apartment had to be done quickly and accomplished jointly with staff from the American Jewish Historical Society, who were also to receive some of the items. Under these circimstances, maintaining any significant original order would have been difficult. In addition, much of the material (from all donations) lacked organization, was not in folders and had been randomly placed in boxes.
One characteristic of Schappes’ files was his creation of individual packets of material which were scattered throughout the collection. He often used clips to hold together related items rather than placing them in folders. For example, an incoming letter or an article of interest would be accompanied by additional research and correspondence, hand written notes and, perhaps, an event flyer or list of citations. In processing the collection, these packets of material were kept together and, in most cases, formed the basis of a titled folder. For materials that were already contained within folders, the original titles were retained to the extent possible.
Correspondence appears in many parts of the collection and, in the case of Jewish Currents correspondence, much of the original order was maintained even though magazine's staff over the years had changed its arrangement scheme from alphabetic by correspondent name to chronological. There are sections of each, as well as specific groups of correspondence such as rejection letters sent to individuals whose submissions to the magazine were not accepted for publication.
A series arrangement was imposed based on the aggregation of Jewish Currents files, identification of personal items and biographical material, and creation of a very large section of subject files reflecting Schappes' wide variety of interests and activities. WBAI broadcast materials and audio files were placed in separate series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Directly related to Morris Schappes’ personal life, this series includes correspondence (1928-2002); biographical articles and brief sketches; interview transcripts and Schappes’ responses to several questionnaires; items associated with the schools he attended and those where he served on the faculty -- Townsend Harris Hall High School, City College of New York (CCNY), Columbia University, Queens College, the Jefferson School and the School for Jewish Studies; documents relating his experiences with the Rapp-Coudert Committee, the Schappes Defense Committee, his time in prison and subsequent parole; materials describing his many personal appearances, lectures and speaking engagements (1943-1994); a selection of his writings -- articles, book reviews and letters to the editor; and ephemera such as identification cards, his wedding ketubah, citizenship papers and copies of personal photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders in this series are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series highlights the role Schappes played in the management of Jewish Currents, serving as its editor from 1958 until 2004. Its three subseries include minutes of the Editorial Board and Editorial Advisory Council, a large amount of correspondence and a variety of administrative files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Minutes of the journal's Editorial Board and Editorial Advisory Council (1962-2002) form the initial Jewish Currents subseries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged chronologically within each organizational unit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists primarily of chronologically arranged letters (1952-2004) including many with attached submissions of stories, articles and poetry. There is also a large group of letters that Jewish Currents staff organized alphabetically by correspondent name. In addition, there are a number of special categories including rejection letters, Management Committee mailings and a few unusual types such as crank letters and letters containing death threats.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically, then in chronological order within category.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of administrative files, touching on many aspects of the magazine's existence such as events, advertising, layout and format, graphics, book review materials, reader questionnaires, drafts and proofs of many articles (including notes), and material associated with Schappes’ column, “The Editor’s Diary.”

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders in this subseries are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: In September of 1966, Morris Schappes began hosting a weekly “Commentary on Jewish Affairs” at FM radio station WBAI, New York. The station advertised the program as “a secular Jewish point of view on contemporary Jewish development in relation to general American issues and in relation to Jewish life and cultural expression in literature and the arts.” This series contains broadcast materials from September 6, 1966 through May 30, 1967. Topics vary and include such titles as “Johnson, the Jews and Vietnam,” “East Side, East Side, A Museum View,” “Black Power and the Jews” and “Morton Sobell on our Conscience”. There are transcripts of the broadcasts along with newspaper clippings, magazine articles, correspondence and notes associated with Schappes’ research and preparation. The series also contains a small amount of material related to other WBAI programs hosted by Jewish Currents in 1981 and 1994.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Broadcasts are arranged in chronological order.

WBAI: "The Middle East: A Breathing Spell -- or Explosion"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The largest by far, this series provides an in-depth look at Morris Schappes’ wide-ranging interests. It is composed of material he collected either as background for his many books, articles, reviews, editorials, letters to the editor, radio broadcasts and classroom teaching, or simply because the items were of interest to him. His annotations are found throughout the many newspaper clippings, articles, event programs, exhibit catalogs, reviews, obituaries and publications in the series.

Emma Lazarus was of particular interest to Schappes. Lazarus-related material includes manuscript drafts, typescript and galleys for his writings along with related notes, clippings, transcriptions of her letters, reviews, press releases, scripts, sheet music and a good amount of correspondence. Black-Jewish relations is another well-represented topic, as is antisemitism, particularly as depicted in Shakespeare’s The Merchant of Venice and Dickens’ Oliver Twist. Other topics of interest include academic freedom, immigration, Communism, secularism, the Red Scare, reproductive rights and Israel. Among the many historical, political and literary figures in whom Schappes took an interest are Saul Bellow, Philip Roth, Ilya Ehrenberg, Roy Cohn, Mario Cuomo, Ernestine Louise Rose, the Foner family (Eric, Henry, Jack, Moe and Philip), Sherwin Wine, Thomas Jefferson and Sally Hemmings, Pete Seeger, and Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. Organizations such as the Jewish People's Franternal Order and such topics as Holocaust history, the Bicentennial of the American Revolution and the Bakke Case are also represented.

A significant portion of the series is devoted to Schappes’ research, much of it identified with either A Documentary History of the Jews in the United States, 1654-1877 or The Jews in the United States: A Pictorial History, 1954 to the Present. There is also general research material on Jewish history, Jewish identity and culture, and Jewish labor history.

A number of book, film and theater reviews are included, along with pamphlets, newsletters, reports and other publications. Of the newspaper clippings and journal articles scattered throughout the series, many are written in Yiddish and a few are in French or Spanish.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders in this series are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The final series is a group of audio cassettes and reel-to-reel tapes and one VHS cassette. Of particular interest are nine interviews with Morris Schappes. Also included are a number of WBAI broadcasts on various topics including The Merchant of Venice, “Women and Orthodoxy,” and Jews and the Black Panthers. Jewish Currents-sponsored events include luncheon speeches, awards presentations and several forums and discussions. On the video cassette, Nancy Savin discusses Emma Lazarus with Schappes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically within each subseries.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements Note
phystech.p: Due to the fragile nature of much of the original media, items in this series must have digital surrogates made before they can be used by researchers. Requests should be sent to tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu. (Note that surrogates are available for several of the interviews.)
